title: Volpone (2009)  by Ben Jonson at the Greenwich Theatre
description:
Volpone by Ben Johnson from Stage On Screen
Recorded live at Greenwich Theatre in London, 2009.

Run time  2 hours 39 minutes presented here with act break at interval.

Summary

Volpone, a rich Venetian nobleman, with the assistance of his servant, Mosca, has devised a method for increasing his wealth by pretending that he is old and dying. Since he has no heirs, the plan is to encourage speculators to curry his favor by visiting him and bringing gifts in the expectation of being named in his will. 

Cast and Creatives

Cast 	
Richard Bremmer,            Volpone
Mark Hadfield,              Mosca
Conrad Westmaas,            Nano
Harvey Virdi,               Androgyno
Edmund Kingsley,            Castrone
Tim Treloar,                Voltore
Maxwell Hutcheon,           Corbaccio
Tim Steed,                  Corvino
James Wallace,              Sir Politic Would Be 
Aislin McGuckin,            Celia
Peter BankolÃ©,              Bonario
Brigid Zengeni.             Lady Would Be

   (other parts played by members of the company)

Credits 

Directed for the Stage by        Elizabeth Freestone                  
Directed for the Screen by       Chris Cowey	
Production and costume designer  Neil Irish
Lighting designer                Wayne Dowdeswell
Composer                         Adrienne Quartly
   
MY notes:

  Volpone is another in the series from Stage on Screen at the Greenwich Theatre.  Earlier, and currently available as a fileshare,  is "The Duchess of Malfi" by numerous members of this same company. 

  As with The Duchess, this Greenwich production is costumed for Italy in the 1930's and features the same stage design as the previous performance of Duchess. 

  Purchase of the Volpone DVD set contains the same kind of teaching materials package as  The Duchess which has a separate In One Mastershot recording of the play seen from the whole stage with entrances, exits and scene changes. That is a tool for teaching theatre technique and is worth the purchase of the dvd set for your library's collection.

Here Volpone is presented in a small size for easy download
